title: Bottle Size Mismatch: 700ml vs 750ml and Why It Matters
metaTitle: 700ml vs 750ml Bottles | Whiskey Selling Guide | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: Why is my bottle 700ml? Learn the difference between US (750ml) and European (700ml) standards and how it affects selling.
summary: How size differences impact pricing and how to photograph size markers correctly.

sections.heading: Quick Answer
content: Bottle size indicates where the bottle was originally sold. This affects value and collectibility.
list: 750ml: Standard US size (and older UK/EU bottles).
The liquid is the sam but the market availability differs.
700ml bottles are now legal to import/sell in the US (since 2020).

sections.heading: US vs Global Market
content: Historically, the US legally required 750ml. Europe standardized on 700ml.
list: If you have a 750ml bottle of a Scotch that is normally 700ml, you have the 'US Release'.
Some collectors prefer US releases for consistency.
Some prefer 700ml because they are often more widely available globally.

sections.heading: Is 700ml Legal?
content: Yes! Ideally, verify this with recent laws, but as of December 2020, the TTB allows 700ml bottles to be sold in the US. This opened the market for global whiskey releases.

sections.heading: Value Differences
content: Usually, the price per ml is similar, but rarity plays a role.
list: A 750ml 'US Exclusive' might trade at a premium if it is harder to find than the global 700ml version.
However, don't assume 750ml is always better. It takes up more shelf space!

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
list: Assuming a 700ml bottle is fake because 'US bottles must be 750'. (It might be a grey market import or travel retail).
Ignoring the 'e' symbol (estimated volume) which usually accompanies 700ml/70cl.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
list: Include the size in your inventory list to get an accurate quote.

faqs.question: What is 70cl?
faqs.answer: Centiliters. 70cl is exactly 700ml. It is the common notation in Europe.

faqs.question: Is 1 Liter valuable?
faqs.answer: 1 Liter (1000ml) usually indicates a 'Duty Free' or 'Travel Retail' bottling. These can be valuable but are distinct releases.

faqs.question: Do you buy 50ml miniatures?
faqs.answer: We generally do not buy individual minis unless they are extremely old or rare sets.
Generally no. Minis are too costly to verify and ship relative to value.

faqs.question: Why did the US change the law?
faqs.answer: To allow easier trade and give US consumers access to global spirits without special bottling runs.

faqs.question: Do Japanese Whiskies use 700ml?
faqs.answer: Yes, domestic Japanese releases are almost always 700ml. 750ml indicates an export version for the US.
